fields.description:
Large files (300GB+ in size) fail to upload using the Eucalyptus User Console. To reproduce:
# Login to Eucalyptus User Console as normal user
# Select S3 Bucket
# Click *Choose Files* and select file larger than 300GB
# Click *Upload Files(s)* to begin file upload
# After about 1-2 minutes upload will fail and return to bucket display screen

The web interface displays only a solid red bar (no text) across the top of the screen to indicate there is an error.

Here is the output from {{/var/log/eucalyptus/eucaconsole.log}}
{noformat}
2015-08-26 12:57:47 CRITICAL WORKER TIMEOUT (pid:2139)
2015-08-26 12:57:47 CRITICAL WORKER TIMEOUT (pid:2139)
2015-08-26 12:57:48 INFO Booting worker with pid: 2913
{noformat}

_NOTE:_ The eucalyptus.log file on the CLC does not produce anything in {{cloud-debug.log}} during uploads.

comments.body:
Some additional details:
* It appears the file being uploaded whole, and not as a multipart upload using the web console
* Directly uploading the entire file from an S3 Client (i.e. CloudBerry Explorer) without multipart upload fails as well
* Large images (InstanceStore and EBS) both are uploaded with the CLI and are sent in 10MB parts without error
We specific limit our uploads to 5Gb. I'll have to look into the error message problem though.

[~tvo], I found an error in some console documentation:
https://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.1.1/index.html#shared/console_object_file_upload.html
It says "The file size limit is 5 TB." which should be GB (not TB)

[~jgallucci32], can I ask which browser you are using? I attached screen shots from our 4.1.2 and current 4.2 development console w/ the expected behavior displaying a warning message and the upload button disabled. This is with a 7GB file.
[~dkavanagh]: Got it.. created ticket DOC-1660. Thanks!!

It is browser independent and has been specifically tested with IE, Edge, Chrome as well as CloudBerry S3 Browser. It appears to be an OSG problem given I can reproduce the problem with S3 tools directly to the bucket.

I should also add that it appears to be a timeout issue, and not one of size. I am able to load 350 GB files everyone in awhile, and the timeout always seems to occur at the same time, regardless of the size of the large‎ file. I am seeing decent transfer speeds (~50 MB/s) to the OSG for smaller files which helps rule out a performance issue.

John Gallucci
BAE Systems, Inc.
858.776.6820

I guess I'm trying to understand if this is a console issue or OSG issue. The console should never allow an upload that large, first from a client-side check, then with a 2nd check on the server side, but that's only after the file has been uploaded to the console server.
Could you make a movie of the problem in case we're missing something critical here as to how to reproduce this?
Thanks, John. I'm going to pass this bug to the back end team as a EUCA ticket since they'll end up acting on this.

Here are some additional details.  When the connection is reset, the following is written to {{/var/log/eucalyptus/cloud-debug.log}}

[~jgallucci32], is this a Eucalyptus cloud running Walrus as the backend or something else? It looks like the failure is in the transmission of data to the backend system that causes the OSG to abort the upload. From what you've pasted it looks like ~500MB files cause this behavior.

Some additional details on the Eucaconsole (I believe we should create a separate ticket for this).  When large, >350GB, files are uploaded to the Eucaconsole, there is ZERO traffic from the Console to the CLC (we have them on separate hosts). This indicates that the console is attempting to cache the file before uploading it to the CLC.  It fails before it can do this.  Same error message as reported in the original ticket.

On a second capture with a smaller file, I was able to verify this caching behavior by the delay of the upload to the console to when the file started uploading to the OSG and S3backend.

Hi [~jgallucci32], I can address the console upload workings. Due to lack of CORS or consistent DNS support pre 4.2, we couldn't implement direct upload to S3 (OSG). Therefore, we needed to proxy files through the console server and imposed a 5GB limit to prevent denial of service from problems like this. We do a check in the browser to disallow larger files (as seen in attached screenshots). If someone were to get around that, we do another check once the file is spooled to the server's disk and again would deny an upload before trying to send to S3. I hope that explains the mechanics a little.
As I mentioned before, if you are *not* seeing a warning about uploading such a large file, I would really like to see how since there must be some case where our checks don't work and I'd like to fix that.

[~dkavanagh], my brain must have been somewhere else 2 weeks ago.  In all my test cases, the problem is with files that are larger than 350MB (MEGABYTES), not GB (I just realized my typo earlier).  This would explain why we haven't seen any warnings I have have not tested any files past the 5GB limit.

Hope that clears some confusion.

Looks like there might be two different issues here - one with euca console and another with OSG itself. Using this ticket for tracking OSG issue. [~dkavanagh] - is there a corresponding issue for the console? 

Reducing the priority to major since there is a work around by adjusting the queue timeout. It is definitely not the ideal way to address the problem. The final solution to this problem would be a part of the ilities work for OSG that might not make it in to 4.2.

[~jgallucci32], I think we haven't properly explored the practical limits of browser-based upload. There are several things that play into the ability to upload larger files. Things like network bandwidth, browser request timeouts, console server storage (hopefully, to a lesser extent). I tried a 400GB file yesterday and it finally timed out. Granted my upstream bandwidth isn't great.
We've discussed implementing multi-part upload which should improve upload robustness, but we just haven't got there yet. The Eucalyptus storage API supports multi-part, but our console does not yet.

[~swathi], correct, there are two different issues here.  Currently I do not see a separate issue to track the problem with the console.  I was able to confirm that the OSG problem is solved using multipart upload.  Using the AWS CLI (vs the s3cmd utility), I was able to upload very large (>2GB) files without any issue.  The {{aws s3 cp}} command apparently has multipart enabled by default using 8MB segments.

For single files, I believe the reason we are seeing timeouts is because our application is broken out into individual servers (CLC, CON, OSG) that are running on separate VMs in VMware.  The slight latency that is added, compounded with the fact that these are not bare-metal servers with 100+GB of RAM, could potentially create timeouts in areas otherwise not seen on test servers with every component on a single node.  This would indicate the application has problems with chatty communications, a common issue seen often with other applications we have tested in the past. This is why I had to tune the queuing and timeout variables in order to get large, single files to upload.

[~dkavanagh], I agree.  Multipart upload needs to be implemented for the console.  Amazon does this today currently, and recommends it for any file over 100MB in size. Honestly, almost every component within Eucalyptus that communicates to the OSG should be using multipart upload. This will improve performance and reliability across the board.
[~jgallucci32], I created GU-2169 to track the console part. Thanks for keeping after us to make things better!

This will be addressed by a related effort to reengineer OSG pipelines using netty and removing mule from the implementation. The incoming pipe needs to be throttled by applying back pressure on lower levels (OS/TCP stack). 

[~vasya], Zach and I had long discussions about this but never had enough cycles to prototype stuff. I started down the netty path during 4.2 but got pulled into higher priority tasks. I think this effort could benefit from [~jhalterman]'s experience with netty. Lets discuss the scope of the work for 4.3.1.
